Represents the number of Web Request invocations that match friendly URL of Liferay CMS page.

When HTTP request goes through FriendlyURLServlet.service(), we can be sure it's a Liferay CMS request (/web, /group or /user) even if external URL was e.g. / or /home (= rewritten by Liferay virtual host filter some service pre action).
measure.id: CMS Pages URI - filter and split (internal, complete internal URI)

measure.description:
Represents the number of Web Request to any Liferay CMS page.
Value will be the full URI as encounterd - it will include any potential portlet URL friendly mapper part (/-/*) in the URI.
measure.id: CMS Pages URI - split (complete external URI)

measure.description:
Represents the number of Web Request to any Liferay CMS page.
The captured value excludes any potential portlet friendly URL mapping in the URI (/-/*) and returns only the portion designation Liferay layout URL.
measure.id: CMS Pages URI - split (external page URI w/o portlet friendly mapping)

measure.description: Represents the number of calls of a method with a specific argument value within a PurePath. Used for Business Transactions.
measure.id: CMS Pages URI - split (internal page URI w/o portlet friendly mapping)

measure.description:
Used as a split to retrieve friendly URL of a site from CMS page URI (internal).
Typically will following transformations: * /web/guest/home -> "guest" * /user/brian/page2 -> "brian" * /group/control_panel -> "control_panel"
measure.id: CMS Pages URI - split (internal site name from URI)

measure.description:
Represents the number of Web Request for Liferay CMS private page (/group/*).
The captured value excludes any potential portlet friendly URL mapping in the URI (/-/*).
Represents the number of calls of a method with a specific argument value within a PurePath. Used for Business Transactions.

Represents the number of Web Request for Liferay CMS public page (/web/*).
The captured value excludes any potential portlet friendly URL mapping in the URI (/-/*).
Represents the number of calls of a method with a specific argument value within a PurePath. Used for Business Transactions.

Represents the number of Web Request for Liferay CMS user private page (/user/*).
The captured value excludes any potential portlet friendly URL mapping in the URI (/-/*)
measure.id: CMS User Private Pages URI - filter (external)

measure.description: Represents the number of calls of a method with a specific argument value within a PurePath. Used for Business Transactions.
measure.id: CMS User Private Pages URI - filter (internal)

Matches every URI. Captures whole URI without query string. Used for splitting the "CSS BTs".

Matches CSS files combined with ComboServlet in Liferay -- URIs beginning with /combo/. Used as one of filters for "CSS BTs".
Example URI: /combo/?browserId=firefox&minifierType=&languageId=en_US&b=6210&t=1383152741000&/html/js/aui/widget-base/assets/skins/sam/widget-base.css

Represents the number of Web Request invocations for Liferay portal login URI. All Liferay SSO filters area mapped to this URI, together with Remember Me autologin filter.
If user can be logged in, redirect is sent to user's landing page. If no filter can authenticate the user, redirect is sent to the page which will render the configured Login portlet (typically the default one, Sign In with portletId 58).
Remember Me is also mapped to all CMS pages (/web, /user, /group), so not all auto-logins via Remember Me cookies will go just through /c/portal/login.

Represents the time spent transferring data for a user action. For page actions the network contribution is calculated by dividing the resource size by the estimated bandwidth. It is assumed that the transferred data is equally distributed using the current bandwidth. For mobile actions the network contribution is calculated by subtracting the server contribution from the overall time the request takes from sending the request, until the response is received.

measure.description: Number of Failed Transactions.
Number of Failed Transactions.
measure.id: Failed Transaction Count of AJAX Request

measure.description: Tags any PurePath that contains a Web Request, which was made by some modern JavaScript library, like AlloyUI or jQuery.
Number of Failed Transactions.
measure.id: Failed Transaction Count of CMS Page Request

measure.description:
Tags any PurePath with Web Request which will be handled as a request for Liferay Content Management System page. The typical Liferay CMS page contains a set of portlets and belongs to some Liferay site or organization's site.
Liferay CMS pages URIs typically start with /web, /group or /user, but when virtual hosts are used for some Liferay site, these might be shortened to just the friendly URL of the page. See Liferay documentation for details on virtual hosts.
Number of Failed Transactions.
measure.id: Failed Transaction Count of CMS Page Request by Page Type - Private Site Page

measure.description:
Tags any web request which will be handled as a request for some private page inside Liferay Content Management System site.
These are often used as site's or organization's pages available only to members of given site or organization. Users typically have to be signed in to have access to these pages.
See business transaction "CMS Page Request" for details.
measure.transactionname: CMS Page Request by Page Type - Private Site Page
measure.id: CMS Page Request by Page Type - Private Site Page

measure.description: Number of Failed Transactions.
measure.id: Failed Transaction Count of CMS Page Request by Page Type - Private User Page

measure.description:
Tags any web request which will be handled as a request for some user's private page inside Liferay Content Management System site. These are often used as each user's private dashboard. Typically only the owner of the page - the user who created it - can access the page (and has to be signed in in order to do so).
See business transaction "CMS Page Request" for details.
measure.transactionname: CMS Page Request by Page Type - Private User Page
measure.id: CMS Page Request by Page Type - Private User Page

measure.description: Number of Failed Transactions.
measure.id: Failed Transaction Count of CMS Page Request by Page Type - Public Page

measure.description:
Tags any web request which will be handled as a request for some public page inside Liferay Content Management System site. These are often used as user's, site's or organization's pages publicly available to anyone who can acess Liferay portal. Users typically do not have to be signed in to acess these pages.
See business transaction "CMS Page Request" for details.
measure.transactionname: CMS Page Request by Page Type - Public Page
measure.id: CMS Page Request by Page Type - Public Page

measure.description: Number of Failed Transactions.
measure.id: Failed Transaction Count of CMS Page Request by Request Type - Process Portlet Action

measure.description:
Tags any web request which will be handled as a portlet action request (JSR 286) on some Liferay Content Management System page.
See business transaction "CMS Page Request" for details.
measure.transactionname: CMS Page Request by Request Type - Process Portlet Action
measure.id: CMS Page Request by Request Type - Process Portlet Action

measure.description: Number of Failed Transactions.
measure.id: Failed Transaction Count of CMS Page Request by Request Type - Render Portlets

measure.description:
Tags any web request which will be handled as a portlet render request (JSR 286) on some Liferay Content Management System page.
See business transaction "CMS Page Request" for details.
measure.transactionname: CMS Page Request by Request Type - Render Portlets
measure.id: CMS Page Request by Request Type - Render Portlets

measure.description: Number of Failed Transactions.
measure.id: Failed Transaction Count of CMS Page Request by Request Type - Serve Portlet Resource

measure.description:
Tags any web request which will be handled as a portlet resource request (JSR 286) on some Liferay Content Management System page.
See business transaction "CMS Page Request" for details.
measure.transactionname: CMS Page Request by Request Type - Serve Portlet Resource
measure.id: CMS Page Request by Request Type - Serve Portlet Resource

measure.description: Number of Failed Transactions.
measure.id: Failed Transaction Count of CSS Server Side

measure.description: Tags any PurePath with a Web Request which is serving a CSS file from server. This could either be a static CSS file or dynamic CSS content assembled by Liferay servlet.
Number of Failed Transactions.
measure.id: Failed Transaction Count of JavaScript Server Side

measure.description: Tags any web request which is serving a JavaScript file from server. This could either be a static JavaScript file or dynamic JavaScript content assembled by Liferay servlet.
Number of Failed Transactions.
measure.id: Failed Transaction Count of Liferay HTTP API Request

measure.description:
Tags any PurePath which contains a Web Request which will be handled by one of the Liferay API services. These are all URIs starting with /api.
Various APIs are available in Liferay, this transaction covers them all: Atom, Axis, JSON, JSON WS, Spring, Liferay.
Number of Failed Transactions.
measure.id: Failed Transaction Count of Liferay Login Request (SSO)

measure.description:
Tags any PurePath containing Web Request which will try to authenticate the user using one of the Liferay SSO handlers or Remember Me cookies. The exact set of handlers depends on Liferay configuration. Uses matching on URI /c/portal/login.
Please note that Remember Me authentication will also be used on any CMS page (/web, /user, /group), so not all auto-login requests using Remember Me cookies will be tagged with this Business Transaction.
Number of Failed Transactions.
measure.id: Failed Transaction Count of Liferay Login Request (non-SSO)

measure.description:
Tags any PurePath containing Web Request which will be authenticating the user into Liferay using username and password provided by the user. Uses code instrumentation on LoginUtil.login().
This Business Transaction does not have a split on username. Data is stored in warehouse, the set of distinct usernames could be very large. For one PurePath, the username can be retrieved by drilling down through the call stack of the pure path.
Number of Failed Transactions.
measure.id: Failed Transaction Count of Liferay Logout Request

measure.description:
Tags any PurePath containing Web Request which will sign the user out of Liferay portal. Uses matching on URI /c/portal/logout.
Used for both SSO and non-SSO authenticated users.
Number of Failed Transactions.
measure.id: Failed Transaction Count of Liferay Signed-in User - Non-UEM

measure.description:
Used to provide information about user identity from Liferays point of view. Matches every PurePath and splits on the user which is authenticated into Liferay. Split values are users userId, screenName and email. Split values are fetched from HTTP session attributes.
Please not that for unauthenticated users, Liferay uses a default user object created for given Liferay instance (and not null).
Number of Failed Transactions.
measure.id: Failed Transaction Count of Liferay WebServer Document Request

measure.description: Tags any PurePath containing Web Request which will be serving a file (its binary content) from Liferay's Document Library through WebServer servlet.
Number of Failed Transactions.
measure.id: Failed Transaction Count of Liferay WebServer Image Request

measure.description: Tags any PurePath containing Web Request which will be serving an image (its binary content) from Liferay through WebServer servlet.
Number of Failed Transactions.

transaction.description:
Tags any web request which will be handled as a request for some public page inside Liferay Content Management System site. These are often used as user's, site's or organization's pages publicly available to anyone who can acess Liferay portal. Users typically do not have to be signed in to acess these pages.
See business transaction "CMS Page Request" for details.

transaction.description:
Tags any web request which will be handled as a request for some user's private page inside Liferay Content Management System site. These are often used as each user's private dashboard. Typically only the owner of the page - the user who created it - can access the page (and has to be signed in in order to do so).
See business transaction "CMS Page Request" for details.

transaction.description:
Tags any web request which will be processing a portlet action (JSR 286). Measures the time Liferay spent on processAction() for given portlet and its sub-calls.
There will be only one call to processAction() per portlet ActionURL PurePath.

measure.description:
Tags any web request which will be processing a portlet action (JSR 286). Measures the time Liferay spent on processAction() for given portlet and its sub-calls.
There will be only one call to processAction() per portlet ActionURL PurePath.

transaction.description:
Tags any web request which will be rendering at least one portlet (JSR 286). Measures the time (sum) Liferay spent on render() for all portlets and method sub-calls.
There can be one or more calls to render() per PurePath, depending on how many portlets are on given page and their window states.
By default, portlets on CMS pages are rendered in parallel on server side (via background thread pool), but some static portlets (like Dockbar) are then rendered serially afterwards. Its not fully precise to aggregate the time taken by render() method execution, since neither sum, avg or max would give reliable picture of how much time was actually spend for rendering of portlets from user's perspective. "Sum" seems to make most sense, even though the number will be an upper bound (due to parallel rendering).

measure.description:
Tags any web request which will be rendering at least one portlet (JSR 286). Measures the time (sum) Liferay spent on render() for all portlets and method sub-calls.
There can be one or more calls to render() per PurePath, depending on how many portlets are on given page and their window states.
By default, portlets on CMS pages are rendered in parallel on server side (via background thread pool), but some static portlets (like Dockbar) are then rendered serially afterwards. Its not fully precise to aggregate the time taken by render() method execution, since neither sum, avg or max would give reliable picture of how much time was actually spend for rendering of portlets from user's perspective. "Sum" seems to make most sense, even though the number will be an upper bound (due to parallel rendering).

transaction.description:
Tags any web request which will be serving a resource from a portlet (JSR 286). Measures the time Liferay spend on serveResource() for given portlet and its sub-calls.
There will be only one call to serveResource() per portlet ResourceURL PurePath.

measure.description:
Tags any web request which will be serving a resource from a portlet (JSR 286). Measures the time Liferay spend on serveResource() for given portlet and its sub-calls.

transaction.description:
Tags any PurePath with Web Request which will be handled as a request for Liferay Content Management System page. The typical Liferay CMS page contains a set of portlets and belongs to some Liferay site or organization's site.
Liferay CMS pages URIs typically start with /web, /group or /user, but when virtual hosts are used for some Liferay site, these might be shortened to just the friendly URL of the page. See Liferay documentation for details on virtual hosts.

measure.description:
Tags any PurePath with Web Request which will be handled as a request for Liferay Content Management System page. The typical Liferay CMS page contains a set of portlets and belongs to some Liferay site or organization's site.
Liferay CMS pages URIs typically start with /web, /group or /user, but when virtual hosts are used for some Liferay site, these might be shortened to just the friendly URL of the page. See Liferay documentation for details on virtual hosts.

measureref.refmeasure: CMS Pages URI - filter and split (internal, complete internal URI)
CMS Pages URI - split (internal page URI w/o portlet friendly mapping)

transaction.description:
Tags any PurePath containing Web Request which will try to authenticate the user using one of the Liferay SSO handlers or Remember Me cookies. The exact set of handlers depends on Liferay configuration. Uses matching on URI /c/portal/login.
Please note that Remember Me authentication will also be used on any CMS page (/web, /user, /group), so not all auto-login requests using Remember Me cookies will be tagged with this Business Transaction.

measure.description:
Tags any PurePath containing Web Request which will try to authenticate the user using one of the Liferay SSO handlers or Remember Me cookies. The exact set of handlers depends on Liferay configuration. Uses matching on URI /c/portal/login.
Please note that Remember Me authentication will also be used on any CMS page (/web, /user, /group), so not all auto-login requests using Remember Me cookies will be tagged with this Business Transaction.

transaction.description:
Tags any PurePath containing Web Request which will be authenticating the user into Liferay using username and password provided by the user. Uses code instrumentation on LoginUtil.login().
This Business Transaction does not have a split on username. Data is stored in warehouse, the set of distinct usernames could be very large. For one PurePath, the username can be retrieved by drilling down through the call stack of the pure path.

measure.description:

transaction.description:

transaction.description:
Tags any PurePath which contains a Web Request which will be handled by one of the Liferay API services. These are all URIs starting with /api.
Various APIs are available in Liferay, this transaction covers them all: Atom, Axis, JSON, JSON WS, Spring, Liferay.

measure.description:
Tags any PurePath which contains a Web Request which will be handled by one of the Liferay API services. These are all URIs starting with /api.
Various APIs are available in Liferay, this transaction covers them all: Atom, Axis, JSON, JSON WS, Spring, Liferay.

transaction.description:
Used to provide information about user identity from Liferays point of view. Matches every PurePath and splits on the user which is authenticated into Liferay. Split values are users userId, screenName and email. Split values are fetched from HTTP session attributes.
Please not that for unauthenticated users, Liferay uses a default user object created for given Liferay instance (and not null).

measure.description:
Used to provide information about user identity from Liferays point of view. Matches every PurePath and splits on the user which is authenticated into Liferay. Split values are users userId, screenName and email. Split values are fetched from HTTP session attributes.
Please not that for unauthenticated users, Liferay uses a default user object created for given Liferay instance (and not null).

measureref.refmeasure: User in Liferay ('userId' from HTTP session)
User in Liferay ('user.getScreenName()' from HTTP session)
User in Liferay ('user.getEmailAddress()' from HTTP session)

incidentrule.description: Connection to a previously connected Application Process/Agent has been lost and agent has not been able to disconnect..
Orderly shutdown of Application Process/Agent.

Agent automatically disabled its instrumentation. Possible reasons are for example that there was no Collector reachable when the Agent was started up or that the overall instrumentation performance on the Collector was too low.
Raises incidents for PurePaths that are corrupted.
Raises incidents for PurePaths that have been truncated as their size exceeds the node limit.
Raises incidents for PurePaths that have timed out as either a method has not returned, or a whole child path did not finish within a certain timeout.
Application Process reported Out-of-memory. A Memory Dump will be automatically triggered if not disabled in the Agent group settings.
Continuous transaction storage is full and we couldn't delete older sessions, so we had to stop continuous recording.
A test violation (test has degraded/improved/failed, or is volatile) occurred.
Custom user created Incidents.
Custom user created incidents for deployment.
The overall failed transaction rate exceeds the configured threshold.
The overall failed page action rate exceeds the configured threshold.
incidentrule.id: High Overall Failed Page Action Rate

incidentrule.description: The average response time (median) is significantly higher than expected. Although the observed response time might be still acceptable for users, this behavior is typically caused by application or infrastructure problems and reduces the maximum throughput you can achieve.
The observed response time for the slowest 10% of requests has increased significantly. This results in poor user experience and can be caused by application or infrastructure problems.
incidentrule.id: Response time degraded for slow requests

incidentrule.description: The rate of failed transactions is significantly higher than expected.
The Application Process has had significant suspension time for a sustained period of time due to spending considerable amount of it's execution time on Garbage Collection.
The Host has had a high CPU usage for a sustained period of time.
The Host has had at least one network interface with high bandwidth usage for a sustained period of time.
The Host has at least one disk with little space available.
The Host has had memory with little space available or considerable amount of page faults for a sustained period of time.
The process thresholds of the host are violated.
Agent lost connection to database
Database Agent does not have privileges to work correctly
Agent connected to unsupported database version. Unpredictable events may occur
Potentially stuck Java VM. It's neither due to a heap/thread dump or GC activity. The reason is unknown and requires manual investigation.
